column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Ecosystem|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Focalpoint|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Locationofstudy|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Mainhypothesisandcorrespondingresults|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Method|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Reccomendationsandsuggestions|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Timeperiodofstudy|
#Text=Population recovery of a migratory anadromous fish in a small forest stream following restoration of longitudinal connectivity.

#Text=Peter M Kiffney,�Joseph H Anderson,�Martin C Liermann,�Erin L Jones,�George R Pess,�Frances Kretschmer\rFirst published: 24 June 2024\r�\rhttps://doi.org/10.1111/rec.14209\rAuthor contributions: PMK, JHA, GRP conceived and designed the research; PMK, JHA, GRP, ELJ, FK performed the surveys; PMK, MCL, ELJ, FK analyzed the data; PMK, MCL wrote the manuscript; PMK, JHA, GRP, ELJ, MLC, FK edited the manuscript.
#Text=Coordinating Editor: John Isanhart\rSECTIONS\rPDF\rTOOLS\rSHARE.
#Text=Abstract.
#Text=Restoration of movement corridors is a key management action used to address threats to migratory and other mobile species.

#Text=Yet, we lack restoration effectiveness studies that allow for species to reestablish naturally ( ie without supplementation) following habitat reconnection that capture all phases (dispersal, growth, and regulation) of recovery, and that takes an ecosystems approach.

#Text=We investigated the natural recovery of migratory anadromous Coho salmon following habitat reconnection across a 5_km section of Rock Creek, a forested tributary of the Cedar River, Washington, United States, 3 km upstream of Landsburg Dam.
#Text=The dam blocked upstream fish movement for 102 years until the completion of a fish ladder in 2003.
#Text=We also evaluated the response of non_migratory trout, which are closely related to Coho salmon.
#Text=Juvenile Coho salmon natal to the Cedar River dispersed into Rock Creek for rearing until spawning there in 2007.
#Text=After restoration, juvenile Coho salmon density (fish/m2) increased 18_fold, approaching an asymptote ( ie regulation phase) a decade later.
#Text=Coho salmon recovery in Rock Creek was spatially variable, however, slowing with distance from the site of restoration.

#Text=Trout density was also higher after restoration relative to before, likely due to several mechanisms, including increased capacity resulting from the reestablishment of marine organic matter subsidies delivered by spawning anadromous fish.
#Text=Our study demonstrates that migratory species can recover naturally after the restoration of habitat connectivity and associated movement corridors.
#Text=Furthermore, our results suggest that such actions can also benefit nontarget species by reestablishing key ecosystem links driven by the target species.

#Text=Implications for Practice\r* Restoration of habitat connectivity can lead to the successful species reestablishment of migratory species.\r* Population recovery of migratory Coho salmon can occur without population supplementation.\r* Distance to the site of restoration, which can be viewed as an index of movement probability, and source population size can influence the recovery of the Coho salmon populations.\r* Restoring habitat connectivity can also lead to an increased density of nontarget taxa, potentially mediated by species interactions.
#Text=Introduction.
#Text=Billions of organisms migrate, including mammals, insects, birds, turtles, and fish.
#Text=These movements can greatly modify the structure and function of their habitats (Bauer & Hoye�2014; Shaw�2016).
#Text=Migratory species are also critically important culturally and economically, such as a source of food and traditional recreation.

#Text=For several reasons, including loss of habitat connectivity, migratory, and other mobile species are imperiled (Horns &  ekercio lu�2018), resulting in significant socio_economic investments to improve degraded conditions.

#Text=Efforts to restore connectivity and associated movement corridors for migratory, anadromous fish, the focus of this study, include dam removal, culvert replacement, and fish ladders (Agostinho et al�2002; Kemp & OHanley�2010; Bellmore et al�2017).

#Text=Despite such investments, there are few efforts assessing the recovery of anadromous fish after restoration of habitat connectivity that capture all three phases (initial, growth, and regulation; sensu Armstrong & Seddon�2008) of population establishment.
#Text=Especially lacking are studies that examine the effectiveness of natural species reestablishment ( ie unassisted) (Anderson et al�2014; Liermann et al�2017).

#Text=Here, we define  initial  as the dispersal of individuals away from natal areas to rear in novel habitats;  growth  as the phase when the population increases at a linear rate after restoration; and  regulation  as the phase when the newly established population approaches a local carrying capacity.

#Text=In a conservation context, a positive asymptotic response after restoration indicates population recovery given local environmental conditions ( ie regulation phase), while a linear response is indicative of ongoing recovery ( eg Bullock et al�2011).

#Text=Long_term restoration monitoring effectiveness studies, especially those that collected pre_restoration data, also provide a unique opportunity to examine spillover effects (Brudvig et al�2009).
#Text=These effects occur when the restoration is associated with changes in nontarget species and/or habitats.
#Text=Likely due to limited resources, studies that investigate the broader ecological effects of restoration on nontarget mobile vertebrates, including freshwater fish, are rare.

#Text=Based on natural history, theory, and prior research, there are three ways a nontarget, mobile freshwater fish could respond to the restoration of habitat connectivity and the reestablishment of migratory species.

#Text=First, if the target species of the restoration is anadromous and semelparous (die after spawning), improved connectivity could positively affect nontarget species due to the reestablishment of biotic interactions that enhances consumer fitness, such as resident organisms consuming organic matter released during and after spawning events ( eg Tonra et al�2015).
#Text=The response could also be positive if restoration of connectivity increased habitat availability for the nontarget species ( eg Duda et al�2021).

#Text=Second, the response of the nontarget species to restoration could be negative because of increased competition for limiting resources with the target species, especially if they overlap in habitat use (Houlahan et al�2007).

#Text=Third, the response to restoration could be neutral if, for example, food and space resources are not limiting and the species display habitat partitioning (Hearn�1987; Buehrens et al�2014; Kiffney et al�2023).

#Text=Here, we report on the natural recovery of migratory, anadromous Coho salmon (Oncorhynchus kisutch) in Rock Creek, a forest tributary to the Cedar River in western Washington, United States, after restoration of habitat connectivity at Landsburg Dam, a barrier to upstream fish migration for 102 years.

#Text=In 2003, a fish ladder built adjacent to this low_head dam reestablished a movement corridor for anadromous and other mobile freshwater species providing them access to 33 km of high_quality freshwater habitat (Anderson & Quinn�2007; Pess et al�2011; Kiffney et al�2023).
#Text=Coho salmon were one of the target species of the restoration (City of Seattle�2000).

#Text=Previous research in Rock Creek reported on the response ( ie growth, survival, and density, movement) of anadromous Coho salmon and nontarget resident trout (O. clarkii clarkii�or coastal Cutthroat trout and�O. mykiss�or Rainbow trout) and sculpin (Cottus�spp.), a small benthic fish, 1_8 years after restoration (Pess et al�2011; Buehrens et al�2014; Naman et al�2014).
#Text=In general, these studies found rapid recovery of juvenile Coho salmon and little evidence that recovery affected resident fish populations ( eg growth).
#Text=We expand on this previous research by a decade, which is approximately three to four generations of the focal species, and spatial extent by about 3 km of stream habitat.
#Text=Increasing the length of the time series provides an exceptional opportunity to examine all phases of natural recovery after restoration for migratory anadromous fish.

#Text=Extending the spatial extent of the study provides insight into how landscape conditions�operating at the scale of kilometers�can influence upstream expansion and thus species recovery (Heino et al�2015).

#Text=Because we conducted surveys before and after restoration, we also had the opportunity to investigate the broader ecological effects of restoration on nontarget species and habitats (Moravek et al�2021).

#Text=Here, we focus on the long_term restoration response of resident trout, which are closely related to Coho salmon and commonly co_occur in small_ to mid_size coastal streams of the Pacific coastal ecoregion (Reeves et al�1998).

#Text=From a conservation perspective, long_term, multi_species studies are necessary, because an improved understanding of the recovery response can inform on project success and future restoration efforts (Lindenmayer et al�2012; T�r�k & Helm�2017).

#Text=Based on our understanding of the system and previous studies ( eg Ahlroth et al�2003), we expected the juvenile Coho salmon population at the scale of Rock Creek to increase after restoration until reaching a local carrying capacity.
#Text=We also expected the annual variation in juvenile Coho salmon density in summer to positively covary with the size of the spawning population (Kiffney et al�2023).
#Text=Potentially due to distance to presumed source populations, we also expected recovery to vary spatially over the scale of kilometers (Kiffney et al�2023).

#Text=We were less certain of how resident trout in Rock Creek would respond to restoration, as previous research indicates this response could be positive, negative, or neutral (Houlahan et al�2007; Buehrens et al�2014; Kiffney et al�2023).
#Text=Methods.
#Text=Study Area.

#Text=This study was conducted in the City of Seattles 364 km2�Cedar River municipal watershed, a de facto forested conservation area, which is off_limits to development and recreation ( Fig�1) (City of Seattle�2000).
#Text=The Cedar River originates in the Cascade Mountains and flows southwest for 72 km to Lake Washington, a large urban lake near Seattle, Washington.
#Text=Ballard Locks on Lake Washington allows migrating freshwater fish access to Puget Sound and the Pacific Ocean (Kiffney et al�2023).
#Text=Landsburg Dam (lat 47 degrees 22 31.42 N, long 121 degrees 57 42.00 W), which forms the western boundary of the municipal watershed, is 35 km from the lake.

#Text=Rock Creek, 3.5 km upstream of the dam, is a major tributary to the Cedar River and provides the majority (approximately 13 km) of available tributary habitat in the watershed (Anderson et al�2008).

#Text=Figure 1\r \rMap of study area in western Washington, United States, showing Landsburg Dam (black and white disc), the Cedar River main stem, Rock Creek reach breaks (dashed orange lines, RC1_RC5), and natural barriers to upstream fish migration (solid orange lines).
#Text=The watershed experiences a temperate, maritime climate, with the rainy season lasting from mid_October to June, followed by drier conditions from early July to late September.
#Text=On average, the area receives 2.5 m of precipitation, mostly as rain.
#Text=The average maximum and minimum air temperature near Landsburg are 24.3 and  0.3 C degrees , respectively, with a mean annual temperature of 8.4 degrees C.

#Text=Stream discharge measured on the Cedar River 500 m downstream of Rock Creek is high (approximately 17.0 m3/s) and variable during the rainy season, with lower (approximately 6 to 8.0 m3/s), more stable flows during the dry season (https://waterdata.usgs.gov/monitoring_location/12117500/#parameterCode=00065&period=P7D&showMedian=false).
#Text=There is no similar discharge record for Rock Creek, but field measurements in August 2002 just above the confluence with the main stem indicated flows of around 3_4 m3/s (Kiffney et al�2006).
#Text=In summer, the Cedar River around the Rock Creek confluence is 20_35 m wide (wetted width), while Rock Creek is about 4_5 m wide.

#Text=Upslope forests in the Rock Creek basin consist of previously logged, mixed_aged stands (approximately 80 to > 180 years old) of large evergreen conifers ( eg Douglas fir [Pseudotsuga menziesii]) and broadleaf deciduous trees ( eg Red alder [Alnus rubra]) and shrubs ( eg Salmonberry [Rubus spectabilis]), which are most abundant along watercourses and wetland areas (City of Seattle�2000).
#Text=There are active gravel roads in the municipal watershed, but they are only used for official purposes and appear to have minimal impact on stream habitat.
#Text=Rock Creek is a cool, heavily_shaded, gravel_bed stream typical of the region.

#Text=Overall, Rock Creek is narrow (11.8 km2�catchment area) consisting of a mixture of fast_water (riffles and cascades) and slow_water (pool and runs) mesohabitats and reaches (Table�S1), except for a wetland complex about 3 km upstream from the Cedar River ( ig�1).
#Text=Mesohabitats are geomorphic units (100_102 m2) commonly used to determine fish habitat preferences (Wolter et al�2016).

#Text=Large wood debris (LWD �0.1 diameter and 1 m long), an important component of habitat complexity in streams, was abundant in Rock Creek relative to similar_sized streams in the region (Riley et al�2001).
#Text=Fish Assemblage.

#Text=Native coastal Cutthroat and Rainbow trout, which mature around age 3, were the only resident salmonids present in Rock Creek before and after restoration (Riley et al�2001; Buehrens et al�2014).
#Text=Coastal Cutthroat trout were the dominant resident salmonid comprising 95% of total trout abundance and biomass before and after restoration (Buehrens et al�2014).
#Text=We considered these populations largely resident to Rock Creek and the Cedar River based on mark_recapture studies (Pess et al�2011; Buehrens et al�2014).
#Text=Anadromous Puget Sound Coho salmon spend, on average, 18 months in both freshwater and the Pacific Ocean before returning to spawn and die in their natal stream (City of Seattle�2000).

#Text=Other abundant native freshwater fish in Rock Creek include several species of sculpin, Speckled dace (Rhinichthys osculus), and Western brook lamprey (Lampetra richardsoni) (Buehrens et al�2014).

#Text=Study Logistics\rData collected during fish surveys in the summer of 2000 and 2001 were used to establish baseline resident trout density (fish/m2) before restoration (henceforth year  2) in reaches RC1, RC3, and RC5 (Riley et al�2001).
#Text=Year 0 was defined by habitat reconnection and the reestablishment of a movement corridor via a fish ladder at Landsburg Dam in September 2003.
#Text=We conducted snorkel surveys in the same reaches in summer (June) and early fall (October) after restoration (2004_2018 or years 1_16 post_restoration).
#Text=To increase spatial coverage, we started summer surveys in RC2 and RC4 in year 4.
#Text=Because of more frequent sampling, we focus our analysis on summer data.

#Text=In the summer of year 9 (2012), a relatively small_scale restoration action occurred at the Walsh Creek_Rock Creek confluence (https://www.seattle.gov/util/EnvironmentConservation/OurWatersheds/Habitat_Conservation_Plan/ManagingtheWatershed/DownstreamHabitat/MetricsBelowLandsburgDam/02_014606.html).
#Text=This included road decommissioning (approximately 1.5 km of road), removal of partial migration barriers, and reconnection of a historic tributary junction (Dr.
#Text=P.
#Text=Kiffney, August 2012, NOAA Fisheries, personal observation).

#Text=While this action improved access to about 4.2 km of stream habitat, we infer any observed changes in fish populations largely to restoration of connectivity at Landsburg Dam, which doubled total habitat in the basin while simultaneously reestablishing anadromous fish populations (Kiffney et al�2023).
#Text=For logistical reasons, we were unable to survey years 0 and 5 and the wetland area within Rock Creek.
#Text=Furthermore, not all reaches were sampled at the same level of effort.
#Text=On average, we sampled 73% of all reaches in summer, ranging from a low of 42% for RC2 to a high of 88% for RC1 and RC3.
#Text=Table�S2�provides a timeline of key activities and events over the course of the study.
#Text=Snorkel Surveys.
#Text=We used snorkeling to quantify stream_rearing salmonid populations (Thurow�1994).
#Text=Surveys started at the first slow_water mesohabitat encountered within a reach.
#Text=Walking upstream from the first mesohabitat, we surveyed every third unit until at least five mesohabitats were sampled.
#Text=Reaches were defined by changes in channel gradient, valley width, LWD, and substrate composition (Riley et al�2001) (Table�S1).

#Text=Survey lengths ranged from 100 to 200 m or about 40  stream wetted width, which approximates the stream length necessary to capture the geomorphic composition of the reach (Kaufmann et al�2022).
#Text=Over the course of the study, we surveyed 377 mesohabitats in summer with a mean surface area of 58 m2�(SD = 54 m2).
#Text=Mesohabitats were the sample unit.

#Text=To estimate fish abundance within a mesohabitat, one to two snorkelers moved slowly upstream, identifying, counting, and classifying Coho salmon and resident trout into size class 1 (</=90 mm in total length or  juveniles ) or class 2 (�90 mm in total length or  adults ).

#Text=It was challenging to differentiate small (<100 mm length) coastal Cutthroat trout from Rainbow trout while snorkeling; therefore, we focus on changes in total trout density, a combination of the two species.

#Text=We estimated fish density for each mesohabitat by dividing fish abundance by mesohabitat surface area (m2), which was determined using a laser range finder (Laser Tech Impulse,�https://lasertech.com) or a stadia rod (Forestry Suppliers,�https://forestry_supperliers.com) (Kiffney et al�2023).
#Text=We acknowledge the uncertainty associated with snorkeling to estimate fish density as a result of imperfect detection and identification.
#Text=However, there are relatively few salmonid species to identify and one of us (P.M.K.) trained all snorkelers and participated in all surveys.

#Text=In addition, snorkeling provided density estimates similar to electrofishing, was effective in all habitats and stream types, and it was less stressful to fish than other methods (Riley et al�2001; Snyder�2003; Kiffney et al�2018).
#Text=Spatial autocorrelation in fish density at the mesohabitat scale within a reach was another potential sampling issue.

#Text=Yet, we were most interested in among_reach variation and results from earlier studies indicate the average distance between study reaches was greater than the average individual movement of the study species (Buehrens et al�2014).

#Text=Adult Coho Salmon\rThe abundance and spatial distribution of juvenile Coho salmon, and possibly resident trout, observed during snorkel surveys were potentially influenced by the number and location of Coho salmon nests above Landsburg Dam, including in Rock Creek.
#Text=Unfortunately, foot surveys to estimate Coho salmon nests in Rock Creek lasted 7 years and fish were only observed spawning three of these years (Dr.
#Text=J.
#Text=Anderson unpublished data).

#Text=Because of these limitations, we explored the potential for species interactions between stream_rearing salmonids in Rock Creek and adult Coho salmon using a 15_year (2003_2018) time series of estimated counts of adult Coho salmon migrating above the dam as an index of annual spawner abundance in Rock Creek (Anderson et al�2015; Unrein�2018; Kiffney et al�2023).

#Text=Support for using the index is evident in the positive linear relationship between the number of Coho salmon nests observed in Rock Creek and the number of adult female Coho salmon dispersing above the dam ( Fig�S1).
#Text=We note there is some uncertainty with this relationship, as the time series is relatively short (n = 7) and it appears to be largely driven by two points.
#Text=Statistical Analysis.
#Text=Juvenile Coho Salmon.
#Text=To quantify the temporal and spatial dynamics of Coho salmon recovery in Rock Creek, we used a Bayesian hierarchical spatial model similar to Kiffney et al (2023) (Supplement�S1).

#Text=With this model, we quantified reach specific median Coho salmon density (fish/m2) in time using a logistic growth function to represent a growing population that eventually reaches a local capacity:\rHere, capr + 0.3 is the reach specific capacity, rater�is the reach specific instantaneous rate of increase, and�Mr�is the reach specific year at which the estimated density equals 0.3 fish/m2.
#Text=We selected this density because it was a value achieved within each reach by the end of the study.
#Text=To avoid zeros, we added 0.01 to the density data and the logistic function.
#Text=Variability around the observed density is assumed to be log_normal with a standard deviation that is reach specific:\rWe used a gamma prior on the precision,�.
#Text=We model the capacity and rate parameters hierarchically.

#Text=That is, while they are reach specific, we assume that they come from common log_normal distributions:\rWe then modeled the year at which half of the capacity was reached,�Mr, as a linear function of river kilometer (distance measured in kilometers from river reach) to the dam,�Dr, with normal residuals:\rAll,� �parameters, the intercept�a, and the slope,�b, were modeled with log_normal priors with mean = 0 and standard deviation = �100.
#Text=We used a half Cauchy prior with variance = 1 for the standard deviation parameters,� �(Gelman�2006).
#Text=We implemented Bayesian models in the BUGS language and used the JAGS software (Plummer�2003) for Markov Chain Monte Carlo integration.
#Text=We used 100,000 simulations, for each of three chains, with a burnin of 10,000 (Supplement�S1).

#Text=To determine whether annual variation in juvenile Coho salmon density correlated with the size of the adult spawning population the previous year (At 1,�n = 15), we conducted Aikaikes Information Criterion for small sample sizes (AICc) model selection in the RStudio platform using the MuMIn package and associated libraries (Burnham & Anderson�2002; R Core Team�2022; Barton�2023).

#Text=In this analysis, we examined the plausibility of three models, including a null model (densityi ~  0 +  i), a linear model (densityi ~  0 +  1(At 1) +  i), and a second_order polynomial model to represent a curvilinear relationship (densityi ~  0 +  1(At 1) +� 2(At 1)2�+  i).
#Text=Resident Trout.
#Text=To quantify the resident trout response to restoration, we used the AICc�model selection procedure described previously.

#Text=Specifically, we used model selection to evaluate all subsets of the global model (densityi =  0 +  1(Y)i +  2(Y2)i +� 3(D)i +  4(D   Y)i +  5(D   Y2)i +  i), which examined the main effects of survey year (Y,�n = 16) and distance to Landsburg Dam (D, km), and the interaction between distance and year.
#Text=The quadratic term for year (Y)2�was added to represent curvilinearity in the temporal response (see Table�S3�for the model set).
#Text=Plots were produced using sjplot (L�decke�2023) and ggplot2 (Wickham�2016).

#Text=Species Interactions\rWe applied AICc�model selection to the same model set used for juvenile Coho salmon to explore the relationship between the summer density of resident trout and the abundance of adult female Coho salmon migrating above the dam the previous year (n = 15 years).
#Text=In all model selection analysis, we focus on models with AICc�differences (�AICi = AICi _ AICmin) less than 2 because they have considerable support (Burnham & Anderson�2002).

#Text=To assess the relative likelihood of a model relative to other models in the set, we used Akaike weights (wi), which are considered the weight of evidence in favor of a particular model (Burnham & Anderson�2002).
#Text=Model fit was assessed using the adjusted coefficient of determination (adjusted�r2).

#Text=Before model selection, we centered survey year by subtracting the average from each year and standardized (z_score) covariates to minimize confounding effects of interaction terms with the original variable and to facilitate interpretation of covariates.
#Text=Results.
#Text=Juvenile Coho Salmon.
#Text=There was no evidence adult Coho salmon spawned in Rock Creek during the first 4 years after restoration.
#Text=Yet, each summer or fall juveniles hatched in the Cedar River were observed rearing in low densities across the lower 3 km of Rock Creek (RC1_RC3) (Figs�S2�&�S3).
#Text=Adult Coho salmon were first observed spawning in Rock Creek in year 4.
#Text=Coho salmon population density grew rapidly after this initial reproductive event ( Fig�2A).

#Text=Mean juvenile Coho salmon density in Rock Creek increased 18_fold between year 1 (0.03 fish/m2) when Coho salmon were detected in 40% of mesohabitats surveyed and year 16 (0.55 fish/m2) when they were detected in 95 % of mesohabitats.

#Text=In year 1, juvenile Coho salmon comprised 10% of total salmonid density, increasing asymptotically until year 10 when Coho salmon in Rock Creek made up almost 70% of total salmonid density ( Fig�2B).

#Text=Figure 2\r \rBoxplots describing the summer distribution of (A) juvenile Coho salmon density (fish/m2) and (B) proportional Coho salmon density (juvenile Coho salmon density/[juvenile Coho salmon density + total trout density]) in Rock Creek after restoration of habitat connectivity at Landsburg Dam on the Cedar River, Washington.
#Text=Year  2 represents before restoration and years 1_16 represent post_restoration data.
#Text=Completion of fish passage occurred in September 2003, or year 0.
#Text=No summer snorkel surveys occurred in years 0 or 5.

#Text=Box plots show 25th (box bottom) and 75th (box top) quartiles, the median (solid line); lines extending from the box, or the whiskers, represent minimum and maximum values, and black dots represent outliers.
#Text=Population recovery of juvenile Coho salmon was spatially variable at the reach scale.
#Text=Mean annual absolute (0.47 fish/m2) and proportional juvenile Coho salmon density (50%) in RC1 was 1.7 and 2.4 times higher, respectively, than RC5 (0.27 fish/m2�and 20%).

#Text=Furthermore, juvenile Coho salmon were not observed in RC5, which is the reach farthest from the dam, until the summer of year 11, indicating recovery rates slowed in the upstream direction (Figs S2�&�S3).

#Text=Results from the Bayesian spatial model support the hypothesis that the juvenile Coho salmon temporal response after restoration was characterized by the logistic model and that this relationship varied with distance from the reach to Landsburg Dam.

#Text=The model predicts juvenile Coho salmon density increased approximately linearly in the first decade after restoration, when the rate of increase slowed around 0.45 fish/m2�between years 8 and 11 ( Fig�3).

#Text=The model also predicts juvenile Coho salmon expansion slowed in the upstream direction as evident in the positive linear relationship between�Mr, the year a reach achieves 0.3 fish/m2, and distance (km) from the reach to Landsburg Dam ( �and [95% credible interval], 2.2 year/km [0.2_4.12]) ( Fig�4).
#Text=For example, the reach closest to the dam (RC1) achieved 0.3 fish/m2�in about 4 years, while the reach (RC5) farthest from the dam achieved this density 7 years later.
#Text=Figure 3\r \rEstimated annual juvenile Coho salmon density (fish/m2) in each reach of Rock Creek (RC1_RC5) in relation to survey year based on the Bayesian spatial model.
#Text=The solid and dashed blue lines are the model fit and 95% pointwise CI.
#Text=Vertical solid lines represent the estimated date at which the reach_specific population achieved a density of 0.3 fish/m2; the dashed lines represent 95% CI.
#Text=Points represent an average of at least five replicate slow_water habitat; points were not displayed for years with missing data.
#Text=Year 0 represents the year restoration was complete.

#Text=Figure 4\r \rThe relationship (solid line) between distance from each reach to Landsburg Dam (km) and�Mr, the estimated year at which the reach_scale juvenile Coho salmon density achieved 0.3 fish/m2�(black dot), based on the Bayesian spatial model.
#Text=Vertical gray bars represent uncertainty in�Mr�(90% credible interval) and dashed lines represent 90% CI for the median predicted�Mr.

#Text=We observed a strong positive relationship between juvenile Coho salmon density in summer and the number of adult female Coho salmon migrating above the dam the previous year, as this single covariate explained 63% of total model variance ( Fig�5).

#Text=Figure 5\r \rBest fit regression line (95% CI shaded) between juvenile Coho salmon density (fish/m2) in summer and adult female Coho salmon migrating above Landsburg Dam, Cedar River, Washington the previous year (At 1).
#Text=Pearsons correlation coefficient (r) represents the strength of the linear association between the two variables.
#Text=Resident Trout\rIn contrast to juvenile Coho salmon, Rock Creek trout densities were relatively stable until about year 9.

#Text=This period of relative stability was followed by a 6_ to 7_year period of overall higher and more variable densities ( Fig�6A�&�6B): mean juvenile and adult trout densities were almost two_fold higher between years 10 and 15 (approximately 0.22 fish/m2) than the previous 9 years.
#Text=Similar to juvenile Coho salmon, trout densities varied at the reach scale.
#Text=On average, juvenile and adult trout densities (0.24 fish/m2) were 2.4_6 times higher in RC5 than downstream reaches (Figs�S4�&�S5).

#Text=Figure 6\r \rBoxplots describing the summer distribution of (A) juvenile and (B) adult trout density (fish/m2) in Rock Creek after restoration of habitat connectivity at Landsburg Dam on the Cedar River, Washington.
#Text=Year  2 represents before restoration and years 1_16 represent post_restoration data.
#Text=Completion of fish passage occurred in September 2003, or year 0.
#Text=No summer snorkel surveys occurred in years 0 or 5.

#Text=Box plots show 25th (box bottom) and 75th (box top) quartiles, the median (solid line); lines extending from the box, or the whiskers, represent minimum and maximum values, and black dots represent outliers.
#Text=The only model with a �AICi�less than 2 predicting annual variation in juvenile trout density was the global model (Tables�S4�&�S5).
#Text=This model predicts juvenile trout density increased curvilinearly over time and with distance to Landsburg Dam.
#Text=Inclusion of the interaction terms indicates that trout density increases were conditional upon distance to the dam.

#Text=Specifically, the top_ranked model predicts the largest increase in juvenile trout density in the reach farthest from the dam, with some evidence that this increase accelerated toward the end of the study, while the reach closest to the dam exhibited little measurable change in density ( Fig�7A).
#Text=We note some uncertainty associated with the top_ranked model.

#Text=Primarily, the confidence interval for the�Y2   D�term overlapped zero, and the top_ranked model was the most complex (df = 7) but explained only 1% more total variance (adjusted�r2) than the second_ranked simpler model (df = 5).

#Text=Figure 7\r \rMarginal effects plot (95% CI shaded) predicting annual changes in (A) juvenile and (B) adult trout density (fish/m2) as a function of distance (km) from reach (RC1 = 3.5, RC3 = 5.0, and RC5 = 7.0) to Landsburg Dam based on the top_ranked model for each size class.
#Text=Year  2 represented pre_restoration, year 1_16 post_restoration, with restoration completed in year 0.

#Text=The only model with  AICc�less than 2 explaining variation in adult trout density included the main and interactive effects of survey year (Y, +) and distance (D, +) from reach to Landsburg Dam (Tables�S4�&�S5).
#Text=Similar to juvenile trout, the interaction term indicates increases in trout density after restoration were conditional on distance to the dam.

#Text=This model predicts the largest increases in density in the reach farthest from the dam (RC5), intermediate in the middle reach (RC3), with no evident change in the reach (RC1) closest to the dam ( Fig�7B).
#Text=The top_ranked model for adult trout explained 21% of total variance and all coefficient estimates did not include zero.

#Text=Species Interactions\rEstimates of juvenile (r2 = 0.35) and adult trout (r2 = 0.48) density in summer positively and linearly covaried with the annual abundance of adult coho female salmon migrating above the ladder the previous year (At 1) ( Fig�8) (Tables�S6�&�S7).
#Text=The 95% confidence intervals for slope coefficient estimates excluded zero.

#Text=Figure 8\r \rBest fit regression line (95% CI shaded) between (A) juvenile and (B) adult trout density (fish/m2) in summer and adult female Coho salmon migrating above Landsburg Dam, Cedar River, Washington, the previous year (At 1).
#Text=Pearsons correlation coefficient (r) represents the strength of the linear association between the two variables.
#Text=Discussion.
#Text=Juvenile Coho Salmon.
#Text=Habitat reconnection at Landsburg Dam and restoration of a movement corridor allowed for the natural recovery of migratory anadromous Coho salmon in Rock Creek after a 102_year absence.

#Text=The growth trajectory of Coho salmon density in Rock Creek following restoration demonstrates that this and similar species are capable of recovering naturally ( ie without supplementation) from habitat isolation in about 10 years, or about three generations for the species.

#Text=We observed similar positive, asymptotic growth of juvenile Coho salmon and mountain whitefish populations in the Cedar River above Landsburg Dam where biomass density reached an apparent plateau eight to 10 years after restoration of habitat connectivity (Kiffney et al�2018,�2023).

#Text=Logistic growth of juvenile Coho salmon density in Rock Creek after restoration of habitat connectivity indicates habitat limitation, which is consistent with other studies examining the establishment of anadromous fish populations in freshwater systems ( eg Pess et al�2014).

#Text=Juvenile Coho salmon densities in Rock Creek were similar or higher then reported in other studies (Pess et al�2011; Kiffney et al�2023), including tributaries to the Elwha River following dam removal that were supplemented with adult Coho salmon (Liermann et al�2017).

#Text=The time it took for the juvenile Coho salmon population to recover in Rock Creek is similar to recovery times for other species and ecosystems following anthropogenic and natural disturbance (Milner et al�2008; Jones & Schmitz�2009; Borja et al�2010).

#Text=Pess et al (2014) found the general time period for establishment of self_replacing anadromous fish populations, regardless of whether the new habitats were newly opened or re_opened, were mostly 10_20 years.
#Text=In an analysis of four case studies conducted across the U.S.
#Text=Rocky Mountain region, it took about 10 years for stream invertebrate assemblages to recover from remediation of historic metal mining impacts (Clements et al�2021).

#Text=Likely due to a variety of environmental factors, including source population size and water temperature, these studies indicate it takes time for organisms and ecosystems to recover, where they approach or reach reference conditions, after disturbance (Heino et al�2015).
#Text=We found that the number of adult female Coho salmon migrating above the dam was an important predictor of juvenile Coho salmon density the following summer.
#Text=We observed a similar relationship in the main stem Cedar River after restoration (Kiffney et al�2023).

#Text=Observing this relationship in both the Cedar River and Rock Creek supports the importance of source population size in determining the recovery response of juvenile Coho salmon in summer; a result consistent with the recovery of a variety of organisms ( eg plants, insects, and mammals) following disturbance ( eg Ahlroth et al�2003).

#Text=Other studies focusing on juvenile fish recruitment have generally found that the size of the spawning stock is often a poor predictor of recruitment except at relatively low stock sizes, which may be the condition in the Cedar River (Walters & Martell�2004).

#Text=Although the juvenile Coho salmon restoration response in Rock Creek after restoration was consistent with logistic growth, the dynamics of the response varied markedly with distance from the site of restoration and putative source populations.

#Text=Results from the Bayesian spatial model indicate recovery of juvenile Coho salmon density in Rock Creek slowed in the upstream direction, with reaches closest to the dam reaching 0.3 fish/m2�first.

#Text=We observed similar results in the 20 km section of the Cedar River above Landsburg Dam, where the recovery rate of juvenile Coho salmon and mountain whitefish, as defined by changes in biomass density (g/m2), slowed upstream from the dam (Kiffney et al�2023).

#Text=We speculate this relationship was due to the probability of an individual moving from downstream to upstream, which was a result of a combination of genetics, behavior, source population size and location, and local habitat conditions (Lawrence et al�2012; WallisDeVries & Ens�2010; Kiffney et al�2023).

#Text=The conservation importance of distance to a putative source of propagules is manifest in a variety of ways, including population genetics ( eg Bj�rklund et al�2010), metapopulation persistence ( eg Johst et al�2002), and the demography of native and non_native plants ( eg No�l et al�2011), stream invertebrates ( eg Tonkin et al�2014), birds ( eg Buxton et al�2014), and fish recovering after disturbance ( eg Pess et al�2012; this study).

#Text=While the evidence supporting the recovery of Coho salmon in Rock Creek is compelling, future response trajectories may shift with changes in climate, biotic assemblages, and downstream land use.

#Text=Moreover, Coho salmon in Rock Creek are subject to interannual variation in marine survival of juveniles and adults as well as harvest, so their abundance and distribution depend only in part on conditions in the river.
#Text=Resident Trout.
#Text=Resident trout densities were overall higher after restoration at Landsburg Dam, indicating potential spillover effects of the management action.

#Text=This result is in contrast to an earlier study in Rock Creek where resident trout growth and survival appeared to be unaffected after restoration of connectivity at the dam and a growing Coho salmon population (Buehrens et al�2014).
#Text=We are unsure of the mechanism(s) driving this difference between studies, but speculate it is due, in part, to a longer time series.

#Text=Elliott (1994) makes the point that long_term studies are necessary to understand many ecological phenomena; especially those, like vertebrate population dynamics, that are driven by slow processes.

#Text=The higher after restoration trout density we observed was consistent with a recent study where total anadromous and resident trout (coastal Cutthroat and Rainbow trout) density was 253% higher following dam removal on the Elwha River, Washington relative to before.
#Text=It was hypothesized that this increase was partly due to the creation of riverine habitat in the former reservoirs (Duda et al�2021).

#Text=Although we observed higher after restoration trout densities, our time series is relatively short, resulting in a nonrepresentative sampling of the restoration response contributing to time_series bias and an inaccurate estimation of the restoration effect (Walters & Martell�2004).

#Text=The resident trout restoration response was also spatially variable, but in a pattern that was the opposite of Coho salmon, as trout density increases positively covaried with distance from Landsburg Dam.

#Text=One logical explanation for this response is that variation in juvenile Coho salmon density, which declined in the upstream direction, potentially reduced the frequency of negative interspecific interactions with resident trout.
#Text=Post hoc correlation (Pearsons) analysis, where we examined reach_scale relationships between juvenile Coho salmon and resident trout density indicated no such pattern in Rock Creek, however.
#Text=Spatial variation in the trout response may also be due to variation in preferred environmental conditions, such as habitat complexity, water temperature, or channel gradient.
#Text=For example, it is generally observed that juvenile Coho salmon prefer low_gradient habitats, while juvenile trout prefer higher_gradient environments (Bisson et al�1988).
#Text=So, the increased density of resident trout in RC5 could be due to the higher channel gradient in this reach relative to other reaches.

#Text=Regardless, our results, in combination with other studies, indicate the biotic response to restoration and other forms of environmental disturbance can vary across the landscape at the scale of kilometers (Lawrence et al�2012; Tonkin et al�2014; Wang et al�2014).
#Text=Species Interactions.
#Text=We observed relatively strong linear relationships between trout density and the abundance of the Coho salmon population the previous year.
#Text=This finding suggests the capacity of Rock Creek to support resident trout was enhanced by increases in adult salmon organic matter and associated energy availability.

#Text=During and after reproduction, anadromous fish release energy_rich organic matter accumulated in the ocean into coastal watersheds, subsidizing food webs and modifying ecosystem processes (Durbin et al�1979; Gende et al�2002; Schindler et al�2013).
#Text=There are several other lines of evidence from our long_term study supporting the marine organic matter subsidy hypothesis.

#Text=In complementary field studies conducted in the Cedar River above the dam, several response metrics ( eg invertebrate abundance) were higher after restoration and were associated with the reestablishment of anadromous fish populations (Moravek et al�2021).
#Text=Moreover, results from flow_through mesocosm experiments conducted adjacent to the Cedar River showed that adult salmon organic matter fueled stream trophic productivity.

#Text=In mesocosms receiving adult salmon organic matter, we observed increased abundance, body size, and growth of several stream invertebrates that are key prey for stream salmonids; increased growth and body size of juvenile Coho salmon; and improved sculpin body condition relative to control mesocosms (Cram et al�2011; Kiffney et al�2014).

#Text=Results from recent field studies in other systems are consistent with the hypothesis that the establishment of anadromous fish populations can influence the structure and function of both native and novel ecosystems (Tonra et al�2015; Munoz et al�2022).

#Text=For example, analysis of natural abundance levels of carbon and nitrogen stable isotopes showed that reestablishment of anadromous fish in the Elwha River, Washington, following dam removal led to rapid uptake of marine organic matter by American Dipper, a small river_dependent bird (Tonra et al�2015).
#Text=While there is support for the marine organic matter subsidy hypothesis, there are caveats to note.
#Text=First, we lack long_term data on the abundance and distribution of adult Coho salmon spawning in Rock Creek.
#Text=These data are important because the ecological effect of spawning is strongly dependent on spawning biomass and watershed characteristics (Hocking & Reimchen�2009).
#Text=Second, we have yet to establish a direct link ( eg ecological and biochemical) between resident trout in Rock Creek and spawning adult salmon, such as observed in Tonra et al (2015).

#Text=Forthcoming isotopic analysis of Rock Creek invertebrates and fish may shed greater insight into the potential ecosystems effects of reestablishing anadromous fish populations on food webs above Landsburg Dam.

#Text=A second explanation for higher trout densities is the fact that the restoration reestablished an historic movement corridor for resident trout in addition to doubling habitat availability (Kiffney et al�2023).
#Text=Partial support for this hypothesis is provided by a video camera within the fish ladder, which shows the upstream movement of hundreds of resident trout each year to access above dam habitat.
#Text=In 2021, the camera identified 216 unique trout dispersing upstream through the ladder; potentially, some of these fish reared and reproduced in Rock Creek thereby increasing summer densities.

#Text=A third explanation for higher after restoration trout densities in Rock Creek could be unmeasured environmental factor(s) that influenced fish populations in comparable ways as observed in other systems (Brooks et al�2002; Houlahan et al�2007).
#Text=For instance, annual variation in prey availability over the course of our study may have been similarly favorable to Coho salmon and resident trout ( eg Pershing et al�2005).

#Text=Collectively, our research on spillover effects of restoration on nontarget species and habitats above Landsburg Dam indicates either positive or neutral effects of restoration and reestablishment of anadromous fish populations (Buehrens et al�2014; Moravek et al�2021: Kiffney et al�2023).

#Text=However, additional targeted field studies, such as manipulations of salmon carcass biomass, and analysis, such as diet and isotopic analysis of resident trout before and after restoration, are necessary to increase our confidence in the marine organic matter hypothesis.
#Text=This case study provides several insights into species recovery after habitat reconnection that are relevant to a variety of species.
#Text=Ecological recovery of Coho salmon in Rock Creek after restoration took about a decade but was variable at the scale of kilometers.
#Text=Earlier studies in Rock Creek showed movement by both adults and juveniles contributed to Coho salmon recovery in Rock Creek (Anderson et al�2008,�2013).

#Text=This observation supports the conservation significance of addressing connectivity constraints for all life stages because doing so may accelerate species recovery (Br�ckmann et al�2010; Kanno et al�2014).
#Text=We also found that habitat reconnection at Landsburg Dam was associated with an increased density of nontarget resident trout.

#Text=We argue lessons learned from our study can be used to inform on population establishment of the same and similar species in newly accessible habitat both within and outside their native range (Pitman et al�2021; Lennox et al�2023).
